I'd say the list of US allies is rather short. If it really came down to it I think Australia, Great Britain, and Canada would support us and that is about it. I don't think that Israel, Germany, Russia, or Japan would really put themselves on the line for the US. France is absolutely not our ally.

 I think in most cases France would side with the US in the war because what is good for us is usually good for France. However France is not going to help the US like we helped them in WWI or WWII. They would not come to our aid if we were overrun and risk themselves.
Mr Jack

France is part of NATO, so they are theoretically bound to come to the US's aid if you were ever invaded. I think they probably would too, and they'd probably come faster than the US joined in on WW-II.
 
 My country (england) would, I expect, send troops immediately. Why, I have no idea. America's treatment of England has been consistently shite (for example: after Sept 11, the British widows of those killed were deported - in some cases being seperated from their children in the process).
 
 Japan's constitution as created by the US prevented them from aiding the US, as did Germany's for that matter. Although I think both have been changed in recent years.
 
 It's all rather moot though; the chances of anyone kicking off a real war with America is about zero.

 France as a rule in history only supports the US when they want something, or need protection from someone else. And keep in mind, the French did not say that there were no WMD, they stated that we should take more time in letting UN weapons inspectors look for WMD, and that we should only invade Iraq within the confines of a UN resolution. 
 
 As far as war, I think AMD has it right. The greatest chance for real war lies in the far east, with Korea and China. The ME will continue to provide conflict and small battles, but true war is not likely. And as far as having the same values, the only value that we all share consistently is money. All wars are economic wars. Other than that, we are very different cultures, societies, and have many different values.

 You are partially correct. France had humongous oil money contracts with Saddam. They were afraid a new regime would not honor them (and I hope they were right!) There were hundreds of BILLIONS of dollars at stake. This is why they did not support the war effort.
 
 They had also sold illegal (by UN sanctions) weapons to Iraq and did not want the world to know. They were on the road to enabling Iraq to produce nuclear weapons. (Israel bombed their French built reactor.)
 
 I have been told that bribes were being paid by Saddam to French and Russian officials.
 
 If you want more info on this, go to the Politics Forum.
 
 http://www.4forums.com/political/showthread.php?t=1962

 The official story was (whether you chose to believe it or not) was that Iraqi AA guns and RADAR were engaging American aircraft. Having RADAR lock on to your aircraft is not a warm and fuzzy feeling, trust me. It is considered a hostile threat, and under the rules of engagement, the target may be engaged and destroyed. I would much rather destroy a surface to air threat than to fly over the next day (or let one of my friends) and get smacked by a SAM. Just a little perspective.

 Hmm.. I would say that this is all a sliding scale. Perhaps France is further away from the "friend" side and closer to the "ally" side (as in military ally) in regard to the US. But to be honest, I don`t think US have that many so far on the "true friends" side of things (perhaps UK, Australia and Canada).
 
 And then we must ask, how is the US acting in regard of France (and other countries). Hardly far to the "true friend" side. And the Suez crisis showed that even UK couldn`t count on US "friendship"...
